at about three o'clock that afternoon, he

3321.82.text: had the first great crisis as army commander.

3325.62.text:
He ordered the 5th Corps south, ordered Warren
to Round Top, ordered Hancock to send help.

3334.92.text:
The 5th Corps arrived division by division,
Barnes, Ayres, and finally Crawford.

3342.50.text:
The monument to Samuel Crawford you might
see just rising above the brush, holding the

3349.42.text:
When Crawford’s division arrived he sent
one brigade to give more support to the other

3358.45.text:
He led his other brigade under William McCandless
down the slope and directly toward the oncoming

3364.18.text:
Confederate troops, and for many of these
Confederates it was simply too much.

3371.34.text: They had been fighting all afternoon.

3381.50.text: In some units he lost over 60%.

3385.28.text:
There was little left in the tank, but there
is a fresh wave.

3391.32.text:
Those 1600 Georgians who had followed behind
Barksdale?

3394.26.text:
They're bearing down along the Wheatfield
Road.

3399.54.text:
Longstreet himself led them toward the Emmitsburg
Road.

3402.44.text:
The men cheered him along and in typical Longstreet
fashion he looked at them and said, "Cheer

3407.30.text:
less, men, and fight more," and that's what
they wanted to do, but now Longstreet will

3416.48.text:
Longstreet sent an order for Wofford to cease
his advance, to cease his attack, because

3422.95.text:
as Longstreet wrote in his memoirs, he knew
the sound of fresh troops arriving.

3429.75.text:
McCandless's brigade was here and another
unit had arrived, much larger; the 13,000

3442.78.text:
After marching 35 miles overnight, they'll
begin to arrive that afternoon and they are

3448.45.text: sent to help restore the left.

3453.69.text:
The Confederate attack ended and the Confederates
will take position in Houck's Ridge and Devil's

3460.34.text: Den, in Rose's Woods and on the Stony Hill.

3464.71.text:
In between the Union line and this new Confederate
line: carnage, destruction, soldiers in blue

3473.28.text:
and gray intermingled and lying one on top
of the other in this 26-acre field of wheat.

3480.14.text:
All the back and forth fighting that we talked
about.

3483.07.text:
There were kepis in that Wheatfield that had
the diamond of the 3rd Corps, kepis that had

3491.90.text:
the cross of the 5th Corps, and the trefoil
of the 2nd Corps.

3497.23.text:
There were slouch-caps from these men from
Texas and Georgia, kepis from officers in

3502.69.text:
South Carolina, all mixed and inter-mingled
among the wheat.

3512.90.text:
One of the Confederates from the 11th Georgia
remembered that: “The rout of the Union

3521.28.text:
army was vigorously pressed to the very foot
of the mountain and nothing but the exhausted

3527.53.text:
condition of the men prevented them carrying
the heights.”

3531.76.text:
Nothing but their exhausted condition and
those freshly arriving waves of Union reinforcements.

3539.70.text:
The battle of the Wheatfield must certainly
rank among the most chaotic and confusing

3544.85.text: fights here at Gettysburg in all three days.

3548.86.text:
A lot of soldiers suffered, a lot of men gave
their lives in this field of wheat.

3554.89.text:
The Union line was ultimately pushed back,
and the Confederates took up the position

3561.79.text:
that Sickles did earlier that day, only they
were now facing east.

3568.30.text:
It was a lot of ground to gain with a lot
of bodies to pay for it, and in the end, the

3575.52.text: Union army was simply driven back where?

3579.78.text: Where they should have been in the first place.

3582.50.text:
So I want to thank you so much for coming
out on my battle walk, I hope you enjoyed

3585.66.text:
it, we do have more programs coming up this
evening, please do take advantage.
